page.title: 08WATER TOWER AT TILE HILL
page.content: Tile Hill Water Tower, which stands in Cromwell Lane, was built in 1932. It is 24 metres high and holds 13,060 cubic metres of water in a single compartment. It is of reinforced concrete and iron, and access to the tank and roof is by a spiral staircase in a tube in the centre of the tank. Between the columns are concrete walls with windows. The tower serves the local area with water, and is a balancing tank for the Coventry distribution system. This means it holds water above the roofs of the houses so that there is a good 'head' of water flowing in the pipes serving Coventry. The water comes from Strensham Treatment Works near Tewkesbury. Recently the tower has been refurbished. The rust has been scraped away, the concrete made good, and it has been repainted.
